title: dunbar-resident-starts-christmas-kindness-campaign-help-others
story: Demi-Lee Taylor, , of Bayswell Road, started a kindness campaign called The Peoplersquos Christmas Miracle, which aims to support families, the elderly and the homeless in East Lothian at Christmas.She asked people to donate clothes, baby items, toys and food to help those in need.The mum-of-two was moved to act in light of her own experiences and from hearing of the problems faced by others.Demi, who is a le coach and an author who writes books for the terminally ill, said: ldquoI have been approached by parents in the school playground who say their children are having to go into school without breakfast some are being bullied because they canrsquot afford to go on school trips.ldquoI hear the elderly limit their food and heating and the homeless are left out in the cold.ldquoI donrsquot believe anyone should suffer, especially at Christmas time. Itrsquos a time for family and friends to get together, no one should be left out.ldquoMany of our elderly and homeless are ex-soldiers and it makes me wonder why the people who fought for our country are just left to live this way.ldquoPoverty in families in this day and age shouldnrsquot exist. Foodbanks are overstretched because so many people are turning to them now for help.ldquoOur children are the next generation and shouldnrsquot be forced into poverty.Demi-Lee used to be on Universal Credit and has seen the impact it has had on todayrsquos society.She added: ldquoIf parents work but still have to claim Universal Credit to bump up their income, theyrsquore told that they earn over the threshold so canrsquot get help. I strongly believe this is how bullying starts because some families can afford things while others canrsquot.And she added: ldquoI came from a poor family: my parents struggled every single day but we got by. It was hard but they managed it and they always gave us a brilliant Christmas.ldquoSome people are embarrassed to ask for help but they shouldnrsquot be. If I can help them I will.One hour after setting up her Facebook page, she was receiving messages and donations from all over East Lothian.She said: ldquoItrsquos amazing to see the community coming together and helping people.ldquoI canrsquot believe the support and reaction, it has been amazing and it is nice to see there are still nice people out there.Demi is holding a bake sale in the Co-op on Dunbarrsquos Countess Crescent from noon on Sunday.And she is also preparing a dinner for  elderly and homeless people on Christmas Day in Dunbar Parish Church.Demi wants to continue her work every Christmas, and hopes it expands beyond East Lothian in future.

title: tranent-youngsters-collect-120-bags-food-foodbank
story: Brothers Archie, , and Finlay Strang, , and their friend Lucas Leishman, , handed out more than  letters to homes in the townrsquos New Row, Edinburgh Road, Market View, Polson Gardens, Bankpark Crescent and Bankpark Grove asking for donations.The younger boys are pupils at Sandersonrsquos Wynd Primary School and Finlay attends Ross High School.They were over the moon at the response of residents who left out more than  shopping bags full of food for them to take to Tranent Libraryrsquos drop-off point for the foodbank.After someone posted one of the letters on social media, the boys were also inundated with requests to pick up food from other locations in Tranent and received an additional  bags.This is the third year that Archie has been collecting for the foodbank.Last year his friend Lucas got involved and Finlay joined their efforts this year.On social media there were dozens of comments praising the actions of the three boys, who were able to collect more than double the amount of food this year than they had managed last year. Raymond Strang, dad to Archie and Finlay, said that he still had a car full of food and more bags to collect from people who had contacted him on social media.He said: ldquoThe boys tried to thank every person personally for making their donation, with Archie saying he is really happy that people in Tranent have continued to support his foodbank appeal.ldquoEvery time they saw someone had left out a bag they were so happy, it was like a gt to them.ldquoThe people we met were so kind to us and Archie hoped that their efforts would help to bring some joy to those who were most in need.ldquoLucas said that everyone he met whilst doing the collection was really nice and it made him really happy to know that he was helping people.ldquoAnd Finlay said that he couldnrsquot believe how much food was being contributed and hoped that next year they could send out more letters to cover more areas. The Tranent people are always so generous and were really kind and complimentary when we thanked them.Foodbank manager Peter Dicker said: ldquoThis was a tremendous effort by three young men showing the pride they have in their own community.ldquoIt was fantastic that they managed to collect so much food for people in the county.ldquoOnce again, East Lothian Foodbank is absolutely astounded by the generosity of people in East Lothian and Tranent in particular.

title: new-look-scottish-seabird-centre-opens-weekend
story: The visitor attraction boasts new mechanical exhibits, interactive games, storyboards and a virtual reality experience.There is also an upgrade to the popular Bass Rock interactive cameras, which show live action from the home of the worldrsquos largest northern gannet colony.All of the elements within the experience have been designed in partnership with a team from Glasgow Science Centre.The Seabird Centre says its new Discovery Experience aims to ldquotransport visitors of all ages from the warmth and comfort of the centre deep into a iety of Scottish marine habits.Focus is on the themes of seabirds, marine habitats and wildle, threats and scientic discovery.It also examines the wonders of marine habitats and the challenges they face, from climate change to marine plastics.The refurbishment also saw upgrades to the centrersquos education centre, cafe and retail space.Susan Davies, CEO of the Seabird Centre, said: ldquoOur refurbishment programme has been both exciting and challenging.ldquoWe are thrilled with the overall refresh of all our exhibits as this strengthens our capability for telling the story of Scotlandrsquos marine environment to erse audiences.ldquo sees us celebrate both our th anniversary, and Scotlandrsquos Year of Coasts and Waters, with a transformed visitor and educational experience.ldquoScotlandrsquos marine environment is exceptional and erse. There is a growing awareness of both its importance and the pressures it is under ndash not least from climate change, invasive species, underwater noise and marine pollution.ldquoOur seas provide vital natural services for society including climate regulation, food provision, renewable energy, scientic discovery and education opportunities. It is important people are aware of its importance and the need to protect it and to use the resources it provides in a sustainable way.ldquoWe look forward to welcoming visitors back to the centre. We hope we will inspire them to embrace the societal changes needed to ensure our marine environment remains healthy and wildle-rich for generations to come.One lucky visitor managed to get an exclusive preview of the centrersquos new Discovery Experience.Pamela Newby, of North Berwick, visited with friends and family last Friday.The -year-old mum-of-two said: ldquoIt is fantastic to see the new-look Scottish Seabird Centrersquos Discovery Experience. The children were all enthralled by the iety of video games and puzzles.ldquoIt was absolutely amazing to be transported to the Bass Rock to roam among the gannets, then swim through the ocean with whales and porpoises using virtual reality. It is a great fun way to introduce children to our marine environment and teach them the importance of protecting it for generations to come.The Discovery Experience officially reopens to the public on Saturday.

title: diary-large-hare-krishna-centre-glasgow-possibly-go-wrong
story: IrsquoM guessing it happens sort of like thishelliptwo guys are drinking in a local boozer, gulping down pint after pint. Perhaps a few whisky chasers come into play in a cunning attempt to dilute all that Tennentrsquos Lager swishing about in their stomachs.But all good things must come to an end, even Saturday night benders. Accepting this grudgingly, the tanked-up twosome sashay and sway from the comfort of the bar, out into the night, where the winter wind slaps them hard across their faces, like a temperance campaigner confronting a pair of naughty bootleggers in prohibition Chicago.Our booze hounds are feeling the pain, alright. But, lo, whatrsquos this they spy  An open door. And a shimmering light emanates from that door. Crossing the threshold theyrsquore confronted by celestial music wafting down a steep staircase. The music draws the men forward. Upward. Climbing the staircase, they enter a room of chanting, dancing, frolicking and blissed-out fervour.Have they perhaps died of alcoholic poisoning on this dreich and rain-dappled Glasgow evening  Slipped the mortal coil and entered the heavenly realm Nope. The drunken duo have accidentally stumbled into OM Sweet OM, a Hare Krishna Centre in Glasgows Oswald Street, where a gathering of the faithful are in full chant mode. Irsquom one of the gang, as it happens, chanting along with about  other people. This being my first time, Irsquove not quite reached the state of transcendental ecstasy everyone  seems to have tuned into with ease.Which is probably why I immediately spot the drunks staggering into the room. And I must admit theyrsquore making me feel more than a wee bit uncomfortable. Whatthe booze bruvs start getting brash, boisterous, bolshiehellip or worse OK, wersquove got them outnumbered,  to two. Butit comes down to a fight, theyrsquove got inebriation on their side. All wersquove got is spiritual enlightenment. And, quite frankly, in a scrap booze beats beatic bliss. Every time.No Morris Dancers hereLuckily the night doesnrsquot turn violent. The drunks wobble amongst us for a while, their eyes wide like small children watching a particularly trippy episode of In The Night Garden. At one point they stagger over to one of the mantra chanters, who happens to be blind, and start to pet her guide dog.But thatrsquos as tactile as they get. Mostly they just stare. And therersquos plenty to stare at. Before arriving at OM Sweet OM, Irsquod assumed Hare Krishna chanting would be laidback and passive. Itrsquos not. For a start, therersquos musical accompaniment. And I donrsquot mean the wispy twang of a solitary sitar. Blokes are playing lead and bass electric guitars while drums provide a hypnotic dance beat.And, yes, plenty of people are getting into the groove. They arenrsquot performing some sort of heavily stylised dance ritual. No Morris dancers here. What Irsquom witnessing is essentially a bunch of rave-heads letting rip. The dancers gain energy and exuberance by grinning manically at each other. Coke-heads behave in a similar manner, though no illicit substances have passed anyonersquos lips this night.At times the dancing morphs into an Eastern version of a ceilidh. The movers and groovers weave in and out of each otherrsquos giddy embrace. All the while the chant continues: ldquoHare Krishnahellip Hare KrishnahellipAt the beginning of the evening I was told the chanting helps focus the mind on the immediacy of the moment. The person meditating is freed from the anguish of the past and concerns over the future. Although Irsquom enjoying the party atmosphere, Irsquom struggling to attain that desired state of being. I remain doggedly attached to my multitude of petty concerns. Even when the drunks leave, as eventually they do, I still find my mind chained to me. Therersquos just no escaping myself.Though to be honest, even without the distraction and enticement of a greasy lump of meat speared on a prong, Irsquod still be hard-pressed to keep my mind focused on spiritual matters. Therersquos no getting away from it, Irsquom a gutter-grubbing sorta guy.Otherwise there would be chaosUnlike Ramunas Bucimskas who is a bona fide Hare Krishna monk who also answers to the spiritual name Raghumath. Once the chant and stomprsquos over for the evening, I grab the opportunity to chat to Ramunas, whorsquos originally from Lithuania, though he left to study IT in Scotland. Irsquom curious to knowthere have been any prior drunken invasions into the Hare Krishnarsquos devotional space. Theyrsquore located in a rowdy part of town, after all, surrounded by pubs, clubs and fast food joints. ldquoOccasionally it happens, says Ramunas with a shrug and a relaxed smile. ldquoWe want to keep a safe environment, so we make sure thatpeople accidentally wander in here, they never cross a certain line. If theyrsquore in a friendly mood, wersquore friendly too. If theyrsquore a little more aggressive, then we have to be a little bit firm and ask them to leave.He adds: ldquoOf course wersquore a peaceable group, but we recognise that a certain level of violence is necessary in society. Thatrsquos why we have a police department, which we support. Otherwise there would be chaos.In other words,things had got really out of hand Ramunas would have called the cops rather than attempting to fend off the intruders by thrusting a locally-sourced radish in their faces. Irsquom glad to hear it.Beatic, Beatlish blissRamunas proceeds to tell me about the International Society for Krishna Consciousness, the organisation behind the OM Sweet OM centre. Itrsquos the same group that George Harrison, that most contemplative of Beatles, supported and promoted throughout much of his le. They teach a brand of Hinduism focusing on yoga, meditation, mindfulness, mantra, music and a plant-based diet.In the early s, counterculture figures such as the beat poet Allen Ginsberg were attracted to their belief system. By that decadersquos end it wouldnrsquot have been entirely far-fetched to label Krishna Consciousness the official religion of the hippies. The musical Hair even had the cast belting out the Hare Krishna mantra.But Irsquom no hippy, and as I admit to Ramunas, I struggled to tap into the spiritual angle of the evening. Does this mean I wasted my time meditating ldquoNot at all, he says. ldquoOf course we offer spiritual guidance. But there are many people who donrsquot have any spiritual beliefs whatsoever. But they practice mediation with us anyway. It helps them on a physical level and makes them feel much healthier.So did I leave feeling healthier  Indeed I did. For all of two minutes. The precise amount of time it took me to stride down the stairs of OM Sweet OM, turn left on Oswald Street, and bound into the kebab shop that had been enticing me all evening. Ten minutes after that, I wasnrsquot feeling healthy at all.I guess itrsquos safe to say that I havenrsquot reached the George Harrison plane of beatic, Beatlish bliss quite yet.

title: herald-diary-born-lose
story: WATCHING Jeremy Corbyn and Boris Johnson march side-by-side into Parliament this week ndash one grim, one grinning ndash was a stark reminder that the lottery of le is all about winners and losers. The Diary often focuses on those two factions as well, as becomes apparent as we look back at some classic tales. Such as the put-upon proprietor of an Italian cafeacute in Perth who owned a wind-up gramophone which became a target for mischief by the local bad lads. The poor cafeacute owner had to repeatedly reprimand the young rogues with the words: ldquoHey, boays. No flickinrsquo the peas doon the hoarna the gramophone. Yoursquoll choke Harry Lauder.Sensitivity trainingSOME jobs entail being a loser in love. Unsociable working hours mean precious opportunities to spend time with a partner rarely arise. Though there are winners in such situations. We were once told of a group of Faslane submariners who were discussing the stress of leaving their families for long periods of time. One of the older, more experienced chaps told the rest of the lads: ldquoYou must be sensitive to your wivesrsquo emotional needs. After a pause he added: ldquoNever, ever, whistle while you pack.Inresen storieSALESMEN are either winners or losers, with nothing in between. We recall the story of a newly hired travelling salesman who wrote his first sales report to the office. Its sheer illiteracy stunned the top brass: ldquoI have seen this lot what hasnt never bot nuthin fromm us, an I sole them a buncha goods for a thousand quid. I am now goin to Manncester. Before he could be given the sack, or at least sent on a course to learn English, there came this letter from Manchester. ldquoI cum hear an sole them haff a millyun. The next morning the two letters were tacked to the staff bulletin board with this memo from the managing director: ldquoWe bin spendin two much time trying to spel instead of sel. You should all get out an do wot he dun.Weighty mattersWErsquoRE mostly discussing the depressing aspects of being a loser, today. Though there are the more positive types of loser, such as those who attempt to offload a bad habit. A few years ago nicotine patches were all the rage. So much so that the Diary received reports of a chap going round with a teabag taped to his arm who said he was trying to give up tea. Not to mention the man with a pie strapped on his arm to seehe could lose weight.Whatrsquos in a nameA MORE recent tale of failure, which appears in this yearrsquos Herald Diary book, A Quacking Good Read by Ken Smith.In the book, Ken relates the story of a spelling error that made a loser of a poor chap called Angus. An email was sent round a global organisation on behalf of this bloke, who happened to be a department head. Unfortunately spellcheck on the email didnrsquot recognise his good Scottish name and omitted the lsquogrsquo. It didnrsquot help matters that the Angus in question had a permanently rather puckered-up expression.Bad loserWE end with a comment from a reader who said he was such a loser,there was ever a competition for losers, hersquod comehellip second.

title: issue-day-fur-flies-cats-movie-panned
story: How bad are the reviews In a word, horrendous. The rsquos film critic, Robbie Collin, said simply that the  million movie is a ldquomesmerisingly ugly fiasco that makes you feel like your brain is being eaten by a parasite.In the , itrsquos no better, with the reviewer saying. ldquothe queasy fears prompted by one of the most disturbing movie trailers ever seen are realised in what is a ldquojaw-dropping feline folly.And others agree The Boston Globe reviewer wrote, "My eyes are burning, while Vanity Fair branded Cats, ldquoan ugly stray who smells bad and should not be invited into your home.So itrsquos a box office flop Who knows yet  Itrsquos just out this weekend and there are surely ardent fans of the live stage version of the Sir Andrew Lloyd Webber extravaganza who may venture out to see director Tom Hooperrsquos feline film, as well as devoted fans of pop star Swt desperate to see her on screen as Bombalurina.But the outlook is grim Itrsquoll be hard to bounce back from the wall-to-wall scathing critiques on both sides of the Atlantic. Empire magazine said: ldquoOur brain will never comprehend it. Itrsquos jarring from the first minute and remains jarring until the last, while Variety summed it up by saying: ldquoNine may not be enough lives for some of the stars to live down their involvement in thishellipItrsquos not the first film to fall on hard reviews On paper, rsquos Absolute Beginners, the musical about London le in the s, starring David Bowie and Patsy Kensit, was destined for success, but was instead, panned by critics.said it was ldquoan over budget turkey of huge proportions, and it was accused of destroying the UK movie business at the time.Isnrsquot that a tad extreme The director, Julien Temple, later recalled: ldquoLegend has it that this was the film that destroyed the British film industry. I had a strange reaction ndash it was a very dark place, a breakdown, generated by the horror of losing control of the film, and the response to it.But it is a bit of a cult classic now Martin Scorsese said it is one of his top  moviesThe biggest box office flop ever Cutthroat Island made the Guinness Book of World Records as, ldquothe biggest financial disaster in all of movie history. The  film, starring Geena Davis, bankrupted the studio that made it.What now for Cats It may come down to making money on the music charts ndash Jenner Hudson sings the standout track, Memory, while Swt has already been Golden Globe nominated for her original song with Lloyd Webber, Beautul Ghosts.MAUREEN SUGDEN

title: unspun-political-diary
story: OUR lsquooh aye rsquo award for the weekrsquos fiest statement goes to the MSP who poured their heart out over election losers. ldquoI want to congratulate successful candidates from all parties and commiserate with the unsuccessful candidates, they told Holyrood. ldquoAs somebody who stood unsuccessfully in two Westminster general elections, I have a good understanding of how they will feel. Eyebrows soared skywards at that one. The tear-stained speaker was one Nicola Sturgeon, she of the frenzied East Dunbartonshire war dance at the defeat of Jo Swinson.High browTALKING of eyebrows, the most expressive pair in politics belong to the SNPrsquos Alyn Smith. The former MEP and passionate Remainer is now in the Commons having won Stirling at the election. His maiden speech yesterday was widely praised, even by hardcore Leavers. As Brexit Secretary Steve Barclay said from the despatch box: ldquoHe spoke powerfully of his opposition to Brexit, albeit by leaving an EU institution to come here, he has started his own Brexit. The famous Smith caterpillars couldnrsquot help but ripple with delight.Mince criesSCANT festive spirit at Bute House this week after the cancellation of the First Ministerrsquos traditional Christmas drinks bash for the media. When thirsty hacks asked her official spokesman about the tragedy, they were told it was meant to be December , but was scrapped because of the election that day. As the election was triggered on October , this explanation was not universally persuasive. ldquoI dunno about Indyref, but shersquos got no mandate for this, muttered one parched scribbler.Repeat after meTHE FMrsquos official spokesman also had an inventive way of rebutting an eve-of-election tabloid story that his boss was downplaying Indyref as it was a vote loser. After insisting this was untrue, he added: ldquoIndependence, independence, independence, independence, independence, independence, independence, independence, independence. A bit vague, but we got the gist.On the nodTHE SNP was in a tizz over Boris Johnson putting two ex-Tory MPs into the Lords to serve in his cabinet on Monday. These ldquounelected Tories were proof of a ldquodisdain for democracy, fulminated a Nat press release. Two days later, the party trumpeted MPs Ian Blackford and Kirsty Blackman being ldquore-elected as the SNP leader and deputy at Westminster respectively. It then turned out both had been unopposed and there had been no election at all. Itrsquos almost asthey were - whatrsquos that word again - unelected Cough upWE also see Mr Blackford is giving up the chair of telecom firm Commsworld Plc after it was sold this week in a deal expected to bag him over poundm. We look forward to reading exactly how much in his Register of Interests. The self-styled ldquohumble crofterrsquorsquo wonrsquot be short of peats this winter.Hatter togetherTHE Scottish Tory press office at Holyrood finds itself with a surfeit of Santa hats after a photocall they were meant to be used in fell flat. But surely everyone wants a Santa hat, you say. Ah, but these ones bear the un-festive greeting ldquoNo to Indyref. Unspun hears at least one piece of the limited-appeal headgear did find a new home this week, however - dangling from a fuddled Labour MSP in a late night boozer off the Royal Mile. A Merry Xmas to you too.

title: rab-mcneil-time-good-cheer-whether-like-not
story: Fear: the only thing that ever works on some people. But fear not, I havenrsquot come here to upbraid anyone, but to get you in the party mood. For wersquore not only on the brink of Crimbo. We are, it says here, on the brink of a Golden Age.Well, thatrsquoll be nice. Brexit is the sleigh that will convey us there, with Boris Johnson at the reins, a chap who is ever full of cheer, a portly Santa in a gravy-stained dinner jacket, who stands a good chance of getting stuck half-way down our chimneys as he brings us the gt of One Nation Conservatism. Personally, Irsquod have settled for socks, but yoursquove just got to grin and say: ldquoThanks, a voucher for the foodbank. Just what Irsquove always wanted.Opposed to Prime Minister Boris is Santa Clause IV, Jeremy Corbyn, who was branded ldquothe Grinch by right-wing papers this week after he appeared to be in a terrible mood. Itrsquos not surprising, since hersquod not only lost the election but had also endured a torrent of abuse during the campaign.Before rolling up for the Queenrsquos Speech in Parliament, he slammed his car door against a television reporter whorsquod been hassling him ootside his hoose. Then, on the way into the Lords, he declined to make the traditional small talk with the affable Mr Johnson, ignoring the blond foprsquos smiling blandishments and looking away.Later, in the Commons, one Tory MP shouted: ldquoSmile, Jeremy, it wonrsquot kill you! Another compared the Labour leader to a ldquochained and regretful Jacob Marley from Dickensrsquo A Christmas Carol.He did looks seriously hacked off, almost dangerously so, which was surprising as,I might mex my mitaphors, all the slings and arrows had been water off a duckrsquos back hitherto. Speaking of potentially dangerous great statesmen, another one hardly in a festive mood was Donald Trump, and no wonder. The Democratsrsquo fruity impeachment has got right up his hump, so to say, though I cannot think why. No one is taking it seriously, and this latest episode of legalism from the liberal elite will see him re-elected President on a landslide. As is the situation with companion elites in Britain, France and where: They. Just. Donrsquot. Get. It.Perhaps the Donling ought to just chill and take in a movie. The new Star Wars film is out in time for Christmas and, while itrsquoll doubtless be liberally sprinkled with PC ldquohomework as usual, itrsquos always fine to escape into Ooter Space and do a moonie at the Dark Side. Back here, on the alleged planet Earth, a film version of the musical Cats has been released. Critics have panned it so itrsquos bound to be a box-office hit.It was also reported this week that yonder YouTube has enjoyed a boom in folk watching old films shot as far back as the s. title: dancers-reveal-dream-irn-bru-tunnocks-tea-cakes
story: And when the women on the front line of the Moulin Rouge in Paris kick off their can-can boots, they dream of comforts rarely found on the streets of Pigalle - Tunnockrsquos tea cakes and Irn Bru.A Scottish flavour has been at the heart of the worldrsquos most famous dance show as it celebrated its th Anniversary this year, with three dancers from Scotland among the ensemble for the first time.Now the gruelling schedule of three performers, from Glasgow, Perthshire and West Lothian are the focus of a new BBC Scotland documentary about the worldrsquos most famous dance show.Moulin Rouge Ecosse follows the lives of Principal dancer Sarah Tandy, from Whitburn West Lothian, Lucy Monaghan from Glasgow and Michaela Rondelli from Almondbank.The programme shines a light on the remarkable commitment required to deliver two physically demanding shows a night on the infamous cabaret with only one day off each week.And it also reveals how the women donrsquot consider the showrsquos topless nudity and skimpy outfits to be regressive, even in the post #metoo era.Solus Productionsrsquo Tony Kearney, director of the documentary to be shown on BBC Alba on Hogmanay, said: ldquoThe world has changed and you do think why is there still a desire for this kind of show  Itrsquos actually very tasteful which maybe wasnrsquot what my impression of it had been before I went. I couldnrsquot have been more wrong. The girls donrsquot have to do that, itrsquos their decision to join the nude line. But itrsquos always over-subscribed.ldquoThe can-can is physical, itrsquos brutal on the body and they donrsquot get home until am every night. These dancers work incredibly hard. But even during the day when they have time off they go to dance classes and fitness classes because they need to keep their body in shape. But they adore it.The hour-long programme goes behind the scenes to meet the formidable characters who run the Moulin Rogue, which was famously the inspiration for the hit  musical film starring Ewan McGregor and Nicole Kidman.It also captures the incredible spectacle of the dancers performing the can-can outside the legendary venue in October this year -  years to the day since it opened in  on the citys Montmatre in the th arrondissement.Michaela Rondelli, , from Almondbank in Perthshire, was auditioned privately for her role in the revue show and feels the nudity is on the womenrsquos terms.The champion Highland dancer said: ldquoItrsquos not vulgar in any way. Itrsquos actually really empowering to be on stage as a woman and to have the choice to do that. Itrsquos great to have the confidence to do that. I know some people wouldnrsquot, but wersquore all strong confident women at work and we all really enjoy it.ldquoBut any time someone goes home they ask what we want brought back from Scotland. Itrsquos always Tunnocks tea cakes and Irn Bru. We might live and work in Paris, but wersquoll always be Scots girls at heart.Sarah Tandy, , from Whitburn has been dancing at the Moulin for  years and is married to fellow Moulin Rouge dancer, Australian David Tandy, with whom she has an infant son Elliott.The principal dancer said: ldquoJoining the Moulin has given me everything ndash a well-paid job, a husband and a family. I started my career at Moulin and thatrsquos where I hope to retire.Returning to the stage after having a child was a challenge for a new mother.ldquoIt was a shock to the system, she added. ldquoIrsquod been off for a full year and went back to work when he was six months old. I had a fear of putting on those costumes again, getting out in front of thousands of people, not being sure that Irsquod be able to do it like I had done before.The programme, presented by Cathy Macdonald, also features trained ballet dancer Lucy Monaghan, from Glasgow a former pupil of the prestigious Dance School of Scotland atKnightswood Academy in Glasgow and Londonrsquos Central School of Ballet.The  year old said: ldquoI started dancing when I was five years old and loved it. I decided when I was ten that I wanted to do this as a career. You canrsquot beat having the opportunity to perform every single night. The theatre holds  people and therersquos never a spare seat. The atmosphere is electric and being part of something so huge, so famous and historic is a real honour.

title: thomas-reid-trying-save-business
story: Thomas Reid, , whose own business was near collapse, broke through two entrances at Malcolmrsquos Antiques in Guardbridge, near St Andrews, before forcing open seven glass display cabinets to get at the jewellery and other items.Staff arriving at the store on a Sunday morning in July found a metal gate had been forced off its hinges and the front door had been prised open.A large quantity of valuable jewellery, including rings, watches and earrings, had been snatched from the display cabinets.The shoprsquos CCTV showed a man breaking into the premises.His face was obscured by his some pieces had been ldquobroken down to sell on.The court was told that Reid, described as a ldquoself-employed antiques dealer, had been selling jewellery online and he had a storage container in the Dryburgh area of Dundee.Defence solicitor Mike Short said Reid had been ldquotrying to save his own antiques business.But the solicitor admitted: ldquoIf he has to behave like this to save the business, itrsquos not savable.He said the pound, values of the goods taken was their retail price ndash the shop targeted had in fact paid pound, to pound, for the items.The court heard earlier that police had recovered a ldquosubstantial quantity of jewellery that had been stolen, but it was estimated about pound, of goods is outstanding.Reid, originally from Glasgow, whose address was given on court papers as Perth Prison, admitted that on July  last year he broke into the shop premises owned by Christine Malcolm, of Malcolmrsquos Antiques, Old St Andews Road, Guardbridge, and stole a quantity of jewellery and ious antique items.Reid was previously jailed for  years at the High Court in Edinburgh for the attempted murder of his cousin Francis Boyle, then , whom he stabbed outside the Tall Cranes bar in Govan in .Imposing the three-year jail term for the jewel raid, Sherf Alastair Carmichael said the  attempted murder conviction was ldquonon-analogous.But he told Reid he had to take into account the high value of the goods stolen, adding, ldquoThere also an element of professionalism about the way you did it.Reid, who has become separated from his we as a result of the title: fidelma-cook-age-get-sick-falter-christmas-magic-like-no-celebrate
story: A huge tree stood before the glass doors, a vision of baubles going back to my childhood ndash a large star touching the ceiling from which a cascade of white lights swathed the branches.Boughs of firs, interspersed with clementines, sprigs of holly and squat church candles, draped chimney pieces and ledges.Pine scent drted with the smoke evoking the forest outside and the smell pulsing from the chimneys of nearby farms where dferent traditions were being followed.A crib with a constantly burning candle to welcome all lost in the darkness, or in case a family needed shelter for a birth, sat on the hall table against the window.In the salon, sweet scented logs crackled and sighed in the wood burner fierce embers burning blood red against the glass. Crystal decanters, filled with whisky and port, twinkled on the gun table my books danced in the reflected light as did the photographs of a busy, mainly joyful, le.Stretched before the heat was Portia, my best beloved of Afghan Hounds, demanding little and retaining an aloofness cast only aside, occasionally, for me, the favoured one.In dferent rooms to the compulsory swelling sounds of Christmas carols, my dearest younger friends, Laura and Steve, here from London, and my still unmarried and carefree son, were dressing.Entranced by the cornucopia of all on offer in the supermarkets and markets at what was then an extraordinarily cheap price, me, the non-foodie, had a kitchen packed with foie gras, guinea fowl, champagne amuse bouches, canapeacutes prepared by the traiteur and wines and champagne at a price that made me laugh out loud with astonishment when they were rung up at the till.Cakes and deserts of trembling perfection awaited in the fridge for those who had need of sweet offerings following such feasts of land, sea and sky.Outside, wrapped in cellophane and sitting on top of my car in the crisp, cold air, was a mountain of sea food from lobster to tiny clams and all permutations in between ndash my order picked up on Christmas Eve from Leclerc  miles away.It was to be our nod to French Christmas, eaten on the eve until long into the early hours. The chapon pintarde was for the day itself.I had a rough idea of what I was to do with it along with the chestnuts, the sauces, the complex vegetables, but, believe thisyou can, I had no worries.For Steve, a journalist who missed his calling as a chef, was my safety blanket, ready to catch me should I falter on merely entering the kitchen which was as much a mystery to me as was my presence here.Just six months earlier I had taken possession of LM in an audacious act of defiance and here we were bathed in endless, unknown possibilities ndash and the unmistakeable magic of Christmas, my favourite time of all.A party had been planned for Boxing Day: open house for all the neighbours in the fields around me the workmen, now friends, who had laboured here the Britons whorsquod welcomed me, and us.I wasnrsquot sure how many would come as open house and a buffet is, even now, a strange concept to my France Profonde neighbours who like the formality of strict times to eat..and a table.But they came, all of them, bearing oysters to be shucked, foie gras to be eaten in chunks of bliss, and stood to the manor born eating from their hand-held plate.The fact that the fosse septique had erupted in the bath and all but one lavatory was ndash said with the benefit of  years on ndash a minor irritant.Men need no encouragement to pee outside ndash women, like camels, can hold it for hours.And my new neighbour Pierrot told me I was his neighbour, therefore his cousin, and he would be around the following morning to sort it out. He was.He has been sorting out many, many, problems in this house ever since and I bless the day we met.Gosh, I find Irsquom growing quite tearful at that memory playing before me like a fast flickering film projected on a wall.Laura and Steve orced my son Pierce is married and the father of two girls ndash I see him rarely. Portia is long gone and another, dficult, Afghan demands constant attention.And me  A breathless shadow of the woman who danced around that kitchen as Mario sang out Joy to the World. A woman who piled her trolley high and laughed at checkouts a woman who sat on her steps that Christmas looking all around her and never imagined the dance would splutter to an end.Thatrsquos le, non  It weaves and wends its way. Nothing, nothing, can stay the same ndash we age, we get sick, we falter and wehellipdisappear.Ah, but Christmas. Christmas has a magic like no other time. Celebrate it. Hold it.Remember it ndash always.Joyeux Noeumll.

title: christmas-gift-minefield-tv-extras-toilet-meddling
story: According to Winkleman: "There are lists, there are panics, theres an eight-year-old who cries because the Barbie isnt the right Barbie. You open a weird candlestick holder in the shape of a watermelon and dont have the heart to ask your cousinshe kept the receipt."Bah humbug, I hear you cry. Well, that was my knee-jerk reaction too. But then the penny dropped: she makes an excellent point.When you think about it, the exchange of Christmas presents is akin to psychological warfare. For a start, there are the eyewatering costs coupled with the anxiety of finding that perfect, heartfelt gt.Then comes plastering on a "Wow, I-truly-love-this-utterly-naff-whatever-it-is" expression after unwrapping a heinous offering, while frantically racking your brains to fathom what on Earth you did to offend that particular person.One of my all-time favourite stories of Christmas presents gone badly awry is the woman who received the baffling gt of three sponges from her husband. "I was told blue was for washing the car, green for the bathroom and pink for the dog," she lamented.Other festive crackers ndash or should that be turkeys  ndash include stretch-mark cream a tin of hamburgers a second-hand broken vacuum cleaner a medley of saucepans a dusty bath set with the previous recipients name-tag still attached and a diary three years out of date.: Susan Swarbrick: Pet portraits, erotic fiction and weird hotel theftsHow ungrateful, I hear you chide, its the thought that counts. Well, indeed,the thought happens to be: "Hold my beer while I nonchalantly offer up a gt-wrapped oddity that I spent less time choosing than I did tying my shoelaces this morning."A face for radioARE you hirsute, missing copious teeth, inhabit either an absurdly large or small body and possess a face that resembles a shrivelled raisin crossed with a battered, leather handbag Then book your ticket to New Zealand where a glittering career awaits as a TV extra. Casting agents for the upcoming, big-budget Lord of the Rings television series are desperately seeking background actors to play Orcs and are urging the hairy, toothless and wrinkled among us to apply.An Orc is a fictional humanoid creature that is part of a fantasy race similar to goblins. In JRR Tolkiens books, they are depicted as ugly and filthy, with a taste for human flesh. They are fanged, bow-legged and long-armed.Two Auckland agencies have issued appeals to fill the roles in Amazons  billionproduction urging those under ft or over ft in with "wonderful noses", "character faces" and "hairy, hairy people of all ages and ethnicities" to sign up.Also being sought are "stocky, mean-looking bikers", "circus performers who can juggle" and anyone who boasts "natural red hair, white hair, or lots and lots of freckles". The fee is around pound per day.Do you know anyone who fits the bill  They could be looking back at you in the mirror. Although word to the wise: being an extra is a tough gig.Ive done it twice. The first was in the BBC drama Case Histories. I arrived on set in Edinburgh to interview the shows star Jason Isaacs. The actor, also an executive producer, extended an invitation to be in the background of a scene being shot in a seedy, underground bar.The crew were aghast, hearts visibly sinking at the thought of their carefully chosen, hipster extras being cast aside in favour of a dowdy writer pushing the wrong side of . But I did it anyway.The second time was in the comedy Still Game. Theres an episode, Balls Up, in the penultimate series where shopkeeper Navid Harrid, played by Sanjeev Kohli, makes an eyewatering, crunching tackle during a walking football tournament As hes sent off, Navid elbows his way through the gathered spectators, including me doing an uncanny impersonation of Edd Munchs The Scream as I hammily tried to convey shock, repulsion and pathos. Believe me, that acting lark is harder than it looks.Sitting uncomfortablyIF you happen to be ensconced on the loo reading this ndash either in paper or digital format ndash then brace yourself. The days of a comfy perch, as some are wont to think of the porcelain throne, could be numbered.A new toilet design has been unveiled with an upper surface that is tilted downwards at a -degree angle to increase strain on the legs, similar to doing a gentle squat thrust.: Susan Swarbrick: Pet portraits, erotic fiction and weird hotel theftsAccording to developers from the start-up company StandardToilet, the design makes it uncomfortable to spend more than five minutes on the toilet ndash a dehumanising gimmick being pitched at employers keen to improve workforce productivity.Talk about a slippery slope. Is nothing sacred  I will personally applaud anyone who comes up with a portable, cleverly shaped cushion to combat this abomination.

title: ulva-island-reversing-decades-decline
story: Under a watery blue winter sky, Ulvarsquos hairy-backed new residents piled side by side on to a small barge for the short journey from Mull, on their way to help breathe fresh le into the Inner Hebridean island.With hooves clattering on the metal deck of the Maid of Ulva, a navy blue and white barge owned by a salmon farm business and loaned for the occasion,  blonde, brunette and raven-haired young Highland heers took their first and highly signicant steps on to the islandrsquos slipway, and towards a new chapter in the islersquos very chequered history.The first fold of Highland heers to set "hoof" on Ulva in countless years is now settling into their new home.Soon theyrsquoll be joined by  more and sent to graze on land which hasnrsquot seen cattle for decades.Of course, on the surface, the arrival of Ulvarsquos newest "residents" may seem slightly underwhelming.However, for islanders, the Ulva fold signies the first gentle steps towards restoring an agricultural presence on an island where dozens of farmers, boat builders, merchants, carpenters, weavers, blacksmiths and tailors once worked, and where, until a few weeks ago, just six people remained.The fold of cowsrsquo first task will be to graze on wild and overgrown former farmland, trampling down the troublesome bracken and restoring a healthy environment for native species to flourish.Eventually itrsquos hoped the fold will play a key role in attracting new farmers: a small but vital part of a larger plan to rejuvenate an almost deserted island which was once home to almost  people.Indeed, the pioneering cows are a small but signicant sign that Ulvarsquos rebirth, sparked by a community land buyout in , is gradually taking shape.ldquoThis is the first stepping stone, says Wendy Reid, Ulvarsquos recently appointed development manager who arrived on the island in September to boost the number of residents to seven.ldquoItrsquos signicant and symbolic to have animals coming back to Ulva. This is the first step towards bringing agricultural beasts back and using them to improve the conditions of the productive land on the island.As well as paving the way towards the reintroduction of farming activities, the cows presence is hoped to help boost bioersity and help support corncrakes and rare species such as the Slender Scotch Burnett Moth.Subtle signs of activity on Ulva come  months after the island celebrated a controversial pound. million community ownership deal largely funded by public money.Some argued it was a harsh day for the islandrsquos owner, Jamie Howard. Recently widowed and whose family had owned Ulva for three generations, his hope to sell to his preferred bidder was removed from his hands by Scottish Government community land reform rules.Others, however, embraced the move as a new dawn for an island which had suffered at the hands of th and th-century owners.In , the population of Ulva and neighbouring Gometra ndash attached by a narrow bridge ndash stood at . Within seven years it would slump to a mere  and by the s, Ulva, a favourite spot for Beatrix Potter, Sir Walter Scott and visited by James Boswell and Dr. Samuel Johnson, would have just seven families left, with crofts abandoned and properties in ruins.Since the change of ownership, however, interest has soared among people keen to visit and, perhaps surprisingly for a remote spot with no car ferry, school, shop or roads, to set up home.Recently a survey by the North West Mull Community Woodland Company Ltd, which as a result of last yearrsquos community buyout owns Ulva, revealed its population could balloon by , per centall applications to become its newest residents were accepted.More than  people have lodged their interest in living on the island: a challenge, given there are currently just a handful of residential properties and no infrastructure other than a single restaurant ndash The Boathouse ndash to support them.There are, however, big plans. And the arrival of the Highland cattle, says Ms Reid, are just the start.By next summer, the six residential properties are expected to have been fully refurbished. The plan includes the restoration of a Thomas Telford-designed manse, built in the s and long abandoned, and there have been hints that its neighbouring church could one day become a music venue.Further ahead, there has been talk of a proper campsite, mini-hotel and hostel for tourists who want to extend their visit, an oyster farm and shops. Itrsquos been suggested that within a decade, Ulva could be home to at least  people, rising to  by .Certainly, there is a major rise in interest: visitor numbers have boomed from around , a year to over , over the course of the past year, raising questions over the tiny islandrsquos ability to cope with the additional footfall.ldquoThere has been a signicant increase in the numbers of people coming across to visit, says Ms Reid. ldquoIt will lead to pressure on infrastructure on the island, but we are working on a number of things to manage it and to give visitors a more erse experienceldquoWe are very aware of the impact of more visitors and we dont want the island to be overwhelmed.Those who made the short journey from Mull during recent weeks may have noticed subtle changes. For a start, volunteers have tackled the overgrown walled garden at Ulva House which, until the buyout, was the fine B-listed mansion home to the Howard family.Plans for the house are said to include refurbishing half to become a high-quality self-catering property which would fund the running of an interpretation and educational centre in the other half.Further plans are understood to focus on the development of infrastructure to support house plots for sale and self-build and for the construction of rented accommodation.If the cattlersquos recent arrival signies a giant leap towards theof an agricultural sector on the island, there is another sign of a new era.Sheila MacFadyen was a dairy maid for the Clark family, Ulvarsquos owners until the mid-th century. The last resident of a row of humble cottages, she left for Mull in the s.She died in , but her blackhouse remained to become a crucial part of island heritage and destination for visitors curious to discover more of the islandersrsquo basic way of le.Work on its restoration is now complete. Even "Sheila" ndash a mannequin which has sat huddled in a corner of the tiny home ndash has had a revamp, and become another highly visible sign of change on Ulva.ldquoThe mannequin had become quite spooky, she was looking tired and ragged, explains Ms Reid.ldquoWe have had a donation of Harris Tweed for a new skirt, and volunteers in Mull are giving her a bit of a new look. Once shersquos had her makeover, shersquoll sit at a spinning wheel that has been done up along with information boards and maps.Sheilarsquos Cottage, she adds, will remain at the heart of island le ndash a vital link with times gone by and a bright new future.ldquoThere has been a huge amount of effort behind the scenes, processes and paperwork and consultations that people canrsquot see.ldquoThe re-thatching of Sheilarsquos Cottage and the arrival of the Highland cows is very symbolic people can see things happening.ldquoWe are planning to announce a number of major plans in the new year.ldquoWe are on the cusp of a new start.

title: johnnie-walker-blue-label-ultimate-80th-birthday-treat-herald-sunday-reader
story: Earlier this month, self-confessed whisky lover Ramsay, from Cumbernauld, decided to try his luck in a giant competition published as part of our Festive Whisky Guide earlier this month, and and was delighted when he got a call from a member of staff telling him that hed won.But when a reporter and photographer turned up at his door on Thursday ndash the big day itself ndash his delight turned to downright amazement.Ramsay ndash accompanied by his we Marion ndash was presented with two suspiciously whisky-bottle shaped boxes, the first wrapped so tightly in bubble wrap, it seemed for a moment he may never get into it. He finally made it through to the most exquisite box, designed by Timorous Beasties, the award-winning Glasgow-based textile design studio.His face lit up as he pulled back the ribbon to unveil a beautul bottle of Johnnie Walker Blue Label Timorous Beasties Edition, with a matching design to the box. The box illustrates flora and fauna found across the four corners of Scotland in a cool blue hue, which complements the golden shade of the whisky. Ramsay couldnrsquot quite believe it ndash even more so when he was informed that the bottle was worth a hefty pound.And that wasnrsquot all. We had another surprise up our sleeve ndash courtesy of Diageo, the maker of Johnnie Walker ndash in the form of a personalised bottle of Johnnie Walker Black Label, inscribed with Ramsayrsquos name.At this point Marion pitched in. ldquoHis name is actually Andrew, which caused a slight panic .ldquoBut he prefers to go by Ramsay because his father had the same name.A sigh of relief briskly followed.Looking like a child in a sweetshop, Ramsay clasped his two bottles in awe for a good few minutes, before having a rather comical photoshoot in his own living room. With an arm around his we, he held the two bottles of fine Scotch with a cheeky grin.ldquoIrsquove never won anything in my le so Irsquom amazed, he said. ldquoBut I like a nice whisky, he laughed.The couple have been married for  years and have lived in the same house in Cumbernauld for  of those. title: ado-coupe-new-sports-car-bringing-motor-manufacturing-back-scotland
story: By Sandra DickA rock-hard bench to sit on. No windows, no roof, no mirrors, not even a steering wheel and with brakes that were optional, signicantly raising the risk should the driver suddenly find themselves heading rapidly downhill.There was a high chance of breaking your wrist on the tiller and the wire wheels had a rather disturbing habit of buckling on corners, throwing the unfortunate occupants on to the road.Scotlandrsquos early motor cars may only have reached a less than hair-raising mph, but those who dared to climb into the rickety horseless carriage of an Argyll Voiturette were almost certainly in for the ride of their lives.It was early , and Scots were about to fall deeply in love with the thrills but hopefully not the spills of motoring, in vehicles carefully hand-built using the best of Scottish engineering skill and technology.Scottish car manufacturing ndash a stop-start affair at the best of times ndash ground to an emergency stop in  when the sprawling Linwood car plant, created in the sixties to churn out countless Hillman Imps, finally closed.Now, a group of Dundee-based motoring enthusiasts is set to relaunch Scottish car manufacturing, with the unveiling of a new sports car designed and built in the city.The lightweight fibreglass-bodied ADO Coupe takes its retro style from a  design for a sporty model intended to replace the iconic MG Midget but which never made it into production.Designed as a modern ldquogreen machine with plans for an electric engine and recycled structure ndash with options to upgrade the engine power for racing enthusiasts ndash the ADO Coupe is thought to be the first car to be made from scratch in Scotland since production halted at the Linwood site.The brainchild of car enthusiast Douglas Anderson, designer Richard Oakes and former Jaguar designer Clark Dawson, it will also become the first vehicle manufactured in Dundee.ldquoI think it is a work of art and pretty sensational, says Anderson, who dreamed of being a car designer since his youth but was thwarted by a lack of opportunities in the Scottish motor manufacturing sector.While the price hasnrsquot been revealed, each ADO Coupe will be built to order ndash not unlike the early Argyll, Albion and Arrol-Johnston horseless carriages which first introduced Scotland to the convenience, relative ldquocomfort and ease of motor car travel.It was, according to Bob James, a guide and research volunteer at Glasgowrsquos Riverside Museum, a fairly bumpy start and one which, unfortunately for those working in the sector, would struggle to really hit top gear.ldquoGlasgow was awash with great engineers, he says. ldquoBut Scotland was probably too far away from the main centres for car manufacturing to make much senseldquoEventually we were losing steel works, aluminium works and engineering skills.ldquoThere was the prospect of lorries having to drive  miles to deliver components to build a car here and the costs increased to a point where it didnrsquot make financial sense.And yet Scottish car manufacturing had set off at a roaring pace at the dawn of the th century when, inspired by the French motor vehicle market, the first all-Scottish cars slowly rolled off the production line.ldquoUntil then, government legislation had protected the toll road owners, the canals and railways which had lobbied strongly saying they couldnrsquot have cars on the road.ldquoThe French were well ahead of us, and there came a point when the British couldnrsquot ignore what was happening any longer, he adds.The change saw a mini-boom in Scottish car-making, led by the ldquoAs ndash Argyll, Arrol-Johnston and Albion, all Glasgow-based manufacturers which brought motorised vehicles to the nationrsquos streets.Leading the way was Springburn locomotive engineer George Johnston, and Forth Bridge engineer Sir William Arrol, who had the first British-built motor car ready to hit the road as the century drew to a close.The Arrol-Johnston six-seater ldquoDogcart, a wood-bodied vehicle started by the pull of a rope, rolled off the production line at a factory at Camlachie on a site close to Celtic Park in Glasgowrsquos east end.Arrol-Johnston vehicles were eventually found on roads around Britain. However, an unfortunate episode which saw its  Victory model sold to the Prince of Wales only to break down during a royal tour brought unwelcome publicity, and the firm folded in .Meanwhile, competition had come from rival Albion, formed in  by two former Arrol-Johnston engineers and with production beginning in a first-floor factory in Glasgowrsquos Finnieston Street. By , however, the business had shted to Scotstoun to cater for emerging demand for lorries and delivery vehicles.A more chequered future, meanwhile, awaited Argyll Motors.Launched in , its Argyll Voiturette was an almost identical copy of a Louis Renault motor car, painstakingly handmade at a former bicycle factory in Hozier Street, Bridgeton.ldquoIt was very basic and looked like a big pram on giant wheels with a very light metal chassis, adds Bob James.ldquoThe gear box, engine and wheels would be built and then it would be a case of finding a body to fit on it. That meant going to old carriage coachbuilders who would adapt horse-drawn coach and carriages to fit on top of the body.The result was a vehicle that occupants didnrsquot so much sit ldquoin but sit perched on top of, he adds.Not surprisingly, there were accidents. ldquoThe Western Infirmary archives have descriptions of ious injuries inflicted on people who had crashes in their cars, he continues.ldquoIt was very common for people to get badly hurt or killed when they were lsquoejectedrsquo from their car.ldquoThe wire wheels would bucklethe driver took a corner too hard and the passengers would be flipped out. Another common injury was caused by the tiller.Two upright rods which were used to steer, the tiller could easily sht suddenly and snap the unfortunate driverrsquos wrist.Argyll Motorsrsquo demise followed the decision to lavish money on the construction of a new factory in Alexandria. ldquoIt was a vast, palatial factory where they planned to build the best cars in the world, he adds.ldquoThey went all-out but while Argyll sold cars in Russia, Japan and Australia, they focused too much on the world market and didnrsquot look after their money.Eventually the expense of constructing the showpiece factory and a sht in demand saw the business stutter and close in .While other smaller manufacturers sprang up around the central belt, including the Madelvic Motor Carriage Company in Edinburgh ndash a specialist in electric vehicles, the derelict factory still stands today ndash none survived.And it would be decades before vehicle manufacturing on a signicant scale ed to Scotland.The pound million Rootes factory in Linwood began production of the Hillman Imp in  and employed over , people at the plant and surrounding suppliers.However, production of the rear-engine Imp ended in . The factoryrsquos new owners, Peugeot-Citroen, ordered its closure in .While a handful of kit car businesses exist, the ADO Coupe is thought to be the first Scottish-designed and manufactured vehicle for a generation.ldquoWe are starting small but we have already got a few customers and the first one should be on the road in early summer next year, adds Anderson. ldquoIt is a bit of a dream come true.The ADO Coupe is being developed at a workshop on the outskirts of Dundee with ious specialist elements of its manufacture to be sub-contracted to local and national suppliers.Its retro body is based on a  prototype sports car developed by BMC as a possible new style of MG Midget. However, the car, which featured a distinctive sloping back end, was never made.Prospective buyers of the Dundee-made ADO Coupe will be able to specy certain design elements, including interior, suspension and engine specications.The vehicle will be available as a road-going vehicle, or as a shell which can be adapted for the race-track. As well as being supplied ready-built, there are also plans to offer it in kit form for car-lovers to build themselves.The designers also have plans to explore using recycled materials to create the bodywork, and electric engines.

title: How Britain   39 woke  39  up in 2019     and what we saw wasn  39 t nice
story: ldquoWoke only entered the Oxford English Dictionary last year as meaning ldquoalert to racial or social discrimination and injustice. Like its parent ldquopolitically correct, woke is a passion of the urban left. It is PC for the age of LGBTQIA+. suggested ldquowoke as word of the year, which arguably it should be, though not for the reason it thinks. For woke has changed meaning in the last  months, and become a term of derision, referring to a style of self-righteous, right-on thinking favoured by, well,columnists. It is now used to denote the metropolitan identity politics that contributed to Labourrsquos greatest defeat since the s.No-one is sure where the word ldquowoke came from, except that it emerged from African-American vernacular for ldquostaying alert, as in ldquostay woke, brother. In recent years it was adopted by the BlackLivesMatter movement with their hashtag #staywoke ndash meaning keeping black issues uppermost on social media.It was soon adopted by white millennials to emblemise not just racial awareness but a whole identitarian outlook on le. Woke expresses the ultra-feminist, multi-ethnic, gender non-conforming culture fashionable in American and UK campuses.Woke people love people of colour and loathe ldquostraight white males, ldquogammon and ldquoboomers. They adore so-called ldquonon-binary people who claim not to identy with any gender. No-one is quite sure what non-binary means. Do they swing both ways  No, thatrsquos bisexual. Are they transgender  Definitely not, and nor are they intersex. Itrsquos one of lersquos mysteries to many folk who are less woke.Wokeness has recently taken the media and advertising world by storm. Companies eager to keep up with the zeitgeist waste no chance to wave the rainbow flag and include multi-ethnic themes. This is sometimes called ldquowoke-washing. Every TV advert from McDonaldrsquos to John Lewis now has to feature a multi-racial family, asthe advertisers believe having two white people on one sofa is racism.The BBC drama Years And Years was kind of Woke Family Robinson. Black professhysional mother, transshygender daughter, gay cousin, asylum-seeker boyfriend, disabled sister ... all fighting the good fight against the emerging fascism of Brexit Britain. This compendium of woke identitarianism came complete with a middle-aged white dad. He naturally emerged as a morally worthless, adulterous creep, fit only to be punished by losing all his money.Woke is easy to satirise and has been, mercilessly, by the comedian Andrew Doyle with his social media creation, Titania McGrath. She is a -year-old middle-class gender studies graduate, obsessed by her imagined victimhood, who identies as an ecosexual, non-binary person of colour and fights for social justice by writing bad poetry. ldquoThe only thing thatrsquos white about me, says Titania, ldquois my skin.She firmly believes women can have penises and that people should have electronic chips inserted in their brains to report heterosexual thinking. Men who have sexual dreams are guilty of rape, according to Titania.Woke folk thought Titania was the product of the homophobic, alt-right, fascist MSMndash or did until her creator, a gay Labour voter, was exposed last year. She is one of the great satirical creations of the century, just donrsquot expect Doyle to get invited on to The Mash Report.Woke is no joke. The leftrsquos penchant for strict identity politics, and the exotic fringes of LGBTQIA+ has had political consequences. The social media assault on ldquowhite working-class Brexit voters as racists and bigots was a factor in the alienation of traditional Labour constituencies. People in Bolsover, Workington and Sedgefield donrsquot much like being portrayed as fascists. Who knew There is a sanctimoniousness and intolerance about woke culture that is itself sometimes redolent of the authoritarian right, especially its approach to language. Anyone who mistakenly says ldquocoloured people instead of ldquopeople of colour, for example, will be ostracised. Pronouns must be obeyed. Feminist academics are no-edthey question whether transwomen are biologically female.Barack Obama warned the Democratic Party to avoid this ldquowoke politics with its ldquocancel culture. This is the practice of social justice warriors on Twitter demonising anyone who fails to conform to their particular form of non-conformism. If Trump wins again, it will in part because the Democrats havenrsquot listened.There is an anti-science, quasi-religious aspect to woke. Woke biology insists that sex is not innate but is ldquoattributed at birth ndash asevery child is born transgender. During the General Election campaign, the Liberal Democrat leader Jo Swinson tried, with disastrous results, to defend the woke dogma that biological sex doesnrsquot exist.Woke wars are raging in the Scottish National Party and have been since Nicola Sturgeon declared her support for self-ID ndash a law change to allow transgender people to self-identy as women without the need for medical intervention or convincing evidence that they have lived as women.There has been a vigorous reaction against this from feminists in and out of the SNP. They fear womenrsquos refuges, changing rooms and prisons are liable to be invaded by men declaring themselves to be female. They also resent being called ldquocis by wokeasians, aswomen are merely a subset of their own sex.The General Election has not caused any obvious soul-searching among the woke cadres. Indeed, the verdict ofwriter Paul Mason was a pitch-perfect expression of the woke worldview. The election was, he declared, ldquoa victory of the old over the young racists over people of colour selfishness over the planet.Such is the firm belief of the morally superior who spend their lives in an echo chamber saving the world from imagined hate crimes. It will take more than a landslide defeat to persuade them otherwise.
